sect1.title: Procedures for Gathering Information

sect2.title: Six Cornerstones of an Evidence-Based Assessment of SSRD

sect3.title: Clinical Interview
sect3.para: Several of the existing existing validated structured/semi-structured interviews include sections to assess SSD and IAD. Symptoms of FNSD and PFAOMC have to be explored through unstructured clinical interviews. There are no validated structured/semi-structured clinical interviews available to assess SSRD in children and adolescents.

sect3.title: Gaining Information from Medical Files and Other Healthcare Providers
sect3.para: SSRD SSRD constitute a group of diagnostic entities in the interface between psychology, medicine, and other disciplines. Therefore, it is crucially important that diagnostic information, if accessible, is gained from medical files and other healthcare providers of a patient in addition to a clinical interview and other procedures of gaining diagnostic information. This information impacts different stages of the diagnostic and treatment process. For example, it makes a difference to plan a psychological treatment for individuals whose symptoms are explained by an identifiable medical diagnosis compared to individuals who present with symptoms that currently cannot be medically explained (e. g., supporting the individual in accepting to have have a diagnosed progressive chronic illness).

sect3.title: Self-Report and Clinician-Rated Scales to Assess Symptoms of SSRD and Associated Features
sect3.para: In addition to clinical interviews interviews , using self-report or clinician-rated scales to assess the symptoms and associated cognitive, emotional, and behavioral features of SSRD is recommended. Moreover, validated scales exist to gain the following additional information that can support the diagnostic process: (a) impact of somatic symptoms on individuals’ physical, social and emotional functioning in their daily life, (b) ways of coping with somatic symptoms, (c) perceived self-efficacy and locus of control, and (d) symptom perceptions (e. g., individuals’ expectations about course and timeline of symptoms).

sect3.title: Prospective Assessment Tools
sect3.para: Memory bias in the the assessment of somatic symptoms is common. Prospective measures, such as symptom diaries, can help individuals to provide a more accurate symptom report. They support the diagnostic process, help with planning the treatment for an individual, and can be used to monitor changes in symptoms during the course of the treatment as well. Some patients might be worried that their symptoms could deteriorate through paying more attention to them and are hesitant to complete a diary. These worries should be validated and the benefits of using a diary emphasized. Individuals should be invited to complete a diary only for a limited period of time (e. g., a week during the diagnostic phase and another week at the end of the treatment).

sect3.title: Informants Other Than Healthcare Providers
sect3.para: Involving individuals individuals from patients’ environment to gain diagnostic information is important for several different reasons. First, as mentioned earlier, the retrospective memory of somatic symptoms and their course can be inaccurate or biased. Therefore, family members and friends of the patients and their observations of the patient’s symptoms in daily life can add important information to the diagnostic process. Second, living with persistent somatic symptoms has an impact on an individual’s social life. It is not uncommon that that patients with SSRD feel disrespected and misunderstood by their social system. Associated with problematic and less supportive social interactions, these patients report decreased self-confidence, avoidant coping behaviors, increased stress, and problematic symptom appraisals. Learning about problems in social interaction both from individuals with SSRD themselves as well as as from their family members and friends offers important information for the diagnostic process.

sect3.title: Behavioral Observation
sect3.para: Observational methods methods are a central part of diagnosing certain SSRD. For example, in individuals with FNSD with motor symptoms, the clinician will have to observe the intensity and quality of the symptoms. Illness behaviors, which are central features of several of the SSRD, can be very subtle, highly automated, and difficult for patients to describe (e. g., body scanning, avoidance behavior). Behavioral observation is needed to identify these behaviors (Oliveira et al., 2018 ; Vlaeyen et al., 1990 ).

sect3.title: Building a Relationship with the Patient’s Healthcare Providers
sect3.para: As mentioned mentioned earlier, gaining information from other healthcare providers plays a central role in the diagnostic process of SSRD. Assuming the patient provides consent, healthcare providers should be contacted, updated about the diagnostic outcome, and a collaborative relationship should be established. If physicians who are involved in the patient’s treatment made a medical diagnosis, it is recommended to gain information about this condition. Being informed when starting the diagnostic process helps patients to feel understood and taken seriously and helps the interviewer to add relevant questions.

sect3.title: Patients with a Biomedical Symptom Model
sect3.para: Many patients with SSRD SSRD struggle with understanding why they are seen by healthcare providers other than physicians. Patients often experience their symptom(s) of primarily somatic but not psychological nature. Being sent to a psychologist or psychiatrist, or statements such as “your symptoms are caused in your brain” can be extremely confusing and can cause patients to feel dismissed or stigmatized as somebody who makes up symptoms. Part of the diagnostic process is therefore to explore how much the patient has already adopted a biopsychosocial than solely biomedical understanding of their symptoms.

sect3.title: Assessing Somatic Symptoms in Persons with Intellectual or Other Disabilities or in Nonverbal Individuals
sect3.para: Cognitive impairment Cognitive impairment has been demonstrated to be associated with an inability to rate symptom intensity with numerical rating scales. Patients who are unable to complete traditional self-report scales may be able to complete verbal pain rating scales that use simple phrases to describe different intensities of a symptom. When communication is impossible or the self-report is discordant, clinicians can resort to observational/behavioral symptom scales. Especially for pain symptoms, several scales have been developed and validated, e. g., the Chronic Pain Scale for Nonverbal Adults with Intellectual Disability (CPS-NAID; Burkitt et al., 2009 ).

sect3.title: Tools to Improve Rapport
sect3.para: Sometimes Sometimes patients with SSRD can experience difficulties with putting their symptom perceptions into words. Creative methods, such as the use of pain cards (Semino et al., 2017 ) or photovoice (Teti et al., 2019 ), can be helpful to facilitate the patient’s description of their problem. These methods can help patients to disclose sensitive and emotional aspects of the impact of the symptoms on their life.

Assessing the risk of self-harming self-harming and suicidal behavior suicidal behavior (Posner et al., 2011 ) is one of the most central steps of the diagnostic interviewing of individuals with FD. It is important to avoid developing prejudice towards patients to be saboteurs. Supportive confrontation and providing the patient with a safe space to disclose are the basic communication tools. Balancing between patient’s autonomy, open communication, the preservation of the patient’s health, and the clinician’s integrity is the basis basis for successful confrontation.
